author: Jessica Gibb
title: Secrets behind Cheryl’s PERFECT hair in TV adverts revealed: extensions, ring lights and camera trickery
text:
On TV adverts, celebrities like Cheryl , Holly Willoughby and Davina McCall have perfect hair. 
As they swish their lustrous locks around to advertise hairspray and dyes – their hair looks impossibly full and healthy. 
And now the secrets behind their bouncy locks have been revealed – and it’s all down to carefully-placed extensions and flashy fluorescent lights. Read More Chloe Ferry continues her bid to become Kylie Jenner with new hair extensions range Cheryl's glossy hair in the Loreal adverts (Photo: Loreal) 
Last night a BBC Horizon documentary called Hair Care Secrets shown on BBC 2 set out to explain how advertisers get hair to look so perfect on TV. 
And how it’s almost impossible to achieve the same polished look as Cheryl in The L’Oreal adverts or Holly and Davina in the Garnier ads at home. 
The show used physicist Helen Czerski as a model and set up a fake advert to show how the tricks are used. Read More X Factor winner Sam Bailey admits to having botox but insists it was for specific health reasons Garnier ambassadors Holly Willoughby and Davina McCall (Photo: Garnier) 
A hair stylist straightened Helen’s hair to make it like a “flat mirror” for light to reflect off. 
She then thickened her hair with extensions to give it more of a “swish factor”. 
But the most important trick was the green screen used on set to employ similar CGI effects as those used in movies. How to get perfect hair just like on TV (Photo: BBC) 
A member of the production team even donned a green bodysuit to become invisible while flicking the model’s hair with a stick. 
“In order to make sure that my hair is falling in exactly the right place we've persuaded one of the team to don a green suit,” the presenter Helen said. 
“Because he is the same colour as the set he can be removed in post-production when the new background is keyed in.” A man in a green suit helped create the perfect flick (Photo: BBC) 
Lastly, the production team used lighting tricks to make hair appear even more shiny. 
“Above we've got these fluorescent tubes which are firing through a trace frame,” the lighting expert said. 
“The trace frame is diffusing it, but it's also making it into a bigger source so this will bring up the area of shine on the top of your head.” Lighting was crucial to create the illusion of high shine (Photo: BBC) 
He also used a ring light – popular with beauty bloggers – that puts a halo of light around the camera. 
“It hides all the wrinkles or imperfections in the skin. It gets into the eye sockets so you don't have bags under the eyes,” he said. 
“And because the lens is firing through the middle, you will get the reflection of the ring light in your eyes.” Like us on Facebook
